title: Consultants claim Labour government under Jeremy Corbyn poses threat to Middle East trade
text:
A Labour government under Jeremy Corbyn would damage UK-Middle East relations and torpedo post-Brexit trade deals, consultants claim.

Britain's biggest trading partners in the region, including the United Arab Emirates (UAE), Saudi Arabia, Egypt and Israel, view Corbyn 'negatively' and 'with suspicion', a report by Cornerstone Global has said.

The consultancy firm claimed that under the Labour leader, relations would 'suffer on the political, economic and security levels' and potentially threaten hundreds of thousands of jobs.

Bad for business: Britain's biggest trading partners in the Middle East view Jeremy Corbyn 'negatively'

The report pointed to Corbyn's alleged snubbing of a meeting with Saudi Arabia's crown prince, his party's bad press in Israel because of anti-Semitism allegations and his 'sympathetic views to Islamic extremists' such as the Muslim Brotherhood.

The only Middle Eastern country he was likely to have warm relations with was Qatar, Cornerstone said, after he met its ruler last year.

Cornerstone said its findings followed conversations with Middle Eastern diplomats and private investors, who saw a future Corbyn government as the biggest risk to their ties with the UK. It said there were 'strong' opportunities to boost UK exports to the Middle East after Brexit, but added: 'The main risk facing any closer UK relations with the Middle East and North Africa is a UK government led by Jeremy Corbyn.

'Middle Eastern states are closely observing the political process in the UK and will only make strategic moves once the threat of a Corbyn-led government subsides.

'Should Corbyn become PM, the UK's relations with the region will suffer on the political, economic and security levels.'

Corbyn has been highly critical of several Middle Eastern countries in the past.

He has repeatedly criticised Saudi Arabia over its human rights record and the murder of journalist Jamal Khashoggi.

Corbyn has accused it of funding terrorist groups and called for UK arms sales to the country to be halted over its bombing campaign against Yemen.

Meanwhile, he was criticised in the past for describing terrorist groups Hamas and Hezbollah as 'friends' and for making a salute linked to the Muslim Brotherhood, angering Arab states who view it as an extremist group.

On top of this, an Israeli minister this year claimed the Labour leader 'hates the state of Israel and hates the Jewish people' amid concerns about the handling of anti-Semitism allegations that have rocked his party.'

Corbyn has repeatedly denied being anti-Semitic.

Cornerstone's report adds: 'A government led by Jeremy Corbyn will not only make it extremely unlikely for most Middle Eastern states to agree on trade deals with the UK, it may also negatively impact existing trade relations.

'The overall impact will be significant potential loss of British jobs, an increase in the security threat and a permanent deterioration in Britain's geopolitical standing in the Middle East, to the benefit of Russia and China.'

It said 250,000 jobs could be threatened. The UK's biggest trading partner in the Middle East is the United Arab Emirates with exports to the country worth £7.8 billion a year. That is followed by Saudi Arabia, with exports worth £3.4 billion, and Qatar with exports worth £2.4 billion.

Exports to Egypt and Israel are next, with both markets worth £1.2 billion to British firms.
